 2. Jobs for Columbians that PREVIOUSLY did not exist. New jobs, not jobs that are replacing other jobs in Columbia.
 3. Less money leaving Columbia for every Toyota sold in Columbia then if the factory was not built. Ie Previously the money per car spent on manufacturing was spent in Japan, putting $4000 into the Japanese economy just from manufacturing, that $4000 now is being spent in Columbia. $4000 fewer dollars leaving the Columbia economy. 
 4. Now lets say Toyota made a net profit of $2000 per vehicle sold in Columbia. At this point it does not matter that the vehicle was built in Japan or Columbia, that $2000 is leaving Columbia. A loss to the Columbia economy.
 
 
 Compared to the US, the benifits are fewer,
 1. Is the same.
 2. Given that US auto manufacturing has an overcapacity ( it can produce more cars then it can sell) the new Toyota plant is replacing jobs, ( witness 25000 GM employess losing their jobs ). For every new job Toyota brings to the US, a higher paying job at GM is lost, that is a negative.
 3. For every Toyota that is built in the US, a GM car is not, meaning a relatively zero benifit to the US.
 4. Again if Toyota was making a net profit of $2000 per vehicle that is $2000 leaving the US.
 
 So a new foreign owned autofactory in a county that has none or an expanding industry is a strongly benifical thing to a generally developing nation. However a new foreign owned autofactory that is being built in country with a mature auto market the benifits are not as high and may cause more money to leave the economy then it brought in.
